plist.p: I suppose I start by welcoming you, ladies and gentlemen, for our half-year results. Also for people who are following us through their webcast, a warm welcome as ever. I'm Jean with René. We're going to first present the highlights of the first half of 2011. We're going to take some time for the outlook – I'm sure you're all interested in that – and after the session that we will divide between René and myself, we will be glad to take your questions. Then I have to get the technical things right, and blink through to the first slide.

We posted in the first half a solid performance. The good news is revenues went up 3.3% during the first half, and that is good news. And group beer volume increased in all the regions, which is quite extraordinary if we take into account that even in Western Europe, volumes were up, and that didn't happen for quite some time. Of course, these results reflect also the strength of our rebalanced portfolio towards more emerging market. The Heineken brands continued to outperform the rest of our portfolio, and our mix improved. On the other hand, our profits increased, both at EBIT level and as net profit beia level. And this went together with substantially increased planned-for marketing support. As these higher investments into marketing, we shifted the focus to accelerate our top-line growth.

Of course we continue to dedicate attention to our footprint, and yet again during the first half we increased our footprint in the emerging markets, where demographic growth goes hand in hand with economic growth and political stability. We completed the Sona Breweries acquisition in Nigeria, mainly designated to increase our capacity footprint in that country. We have entered Ethiopia with the acquisitions of two state-owned breweries. We have again extended our capacities in South Africa. We added capacity in Vietnam. And finally, we opened a new brewery in Guangzhou, China, entirely dedicated to the production of Heineken beer and Tiger beer.

Next to that, our cost and cash flow programs continue to deliver. As you can see from the chart, we posted again an €80 million TCM savings on the half year, and the free operating cash flow stands at €779 million, up 11% towards last year, so a very strong cash flow performance. We continued to make progress on our recently acquired breweries, and notably, we improved the profitability in Scottish & Newcastle and also in FEMSA. Those are the highlights of the first half 2011.

Let me now go to the next slide. As we told you in February, we would plan for higher marketing spend. The organic spend in the first half was 6%, up towards last year, and it goes into an array of initiatives. And I just want to highlight with you a few of the more important ones, where the money goes to. We have been launching a new Heineken global campaign around the theme "Open Your World." We have devoted a lot of energy, money, and time to the activation of the brand here in the UK, launching the campaign but also organizing the Heineken Cup and the Champions League, which the final was organized here in London, so we kind of painted the city in green for that weekend.

We have announced a number of innovations ahead of the key summer selling period. We launched Strongbow cider in Italy. We have been launching Desperados, which is our tequila-based beer, in 10 new markets: Spain, Austria, Ireland, Croatia, Switzerland, Romania, Netherlands, Belgium, Portugal, and Bulgaria. We, typically, increased quite substantially our spendings in the U.S., Mexico, Brazil, Italy, and Nigeria. Those were the key markets where we concentrated on.

And we continue to devote a lot of energy and spendings behind innovation, in view of what we announced already last year, that we want to double our innovation rate from 3% to 6% by 2020. Innovations in our industry are important to continue to attract and retain consumers. It targets not only the beer but also the near-beer segment, mixed drinks, and cider. It's a key driver for improving our mix, if you will. And in some cases, innovation is even reducing costs, like the introduction of the new model of Heineken bottle all across the world, code named K2. There's not only an innovation in it, per se, but it's also a cost-saving exercise.

We had a lot of new innovation the first half, non-alcohol beer in Spain and Romania, just to name a few. We launched a line extension of Amstel – Amstel Premium Pilsner in Russia and Greece. We launched a new PET soft dispensing DraughtKeg in the Netherlands with Amstel and Heineken. And we did a lot of flavor and line extensions in Central Europe, called Radler in number of countries, with high margins, high growth profile. So we developed – just to give you a flavor of all – where the money goes and what kind of initiatives we are taking.

On the next slide is to talk to you a little bit about – well, spending is one thing, but it's obviously the creative execution of how you spend the money that's going to make the difference. And we attached a lot of attention also – you have to be talked about, be part of the conversation in what you do. That builds the reputation of a brand, is that you're talked about. And so in the execution, we devote a lot of, again, efforts to make sure that we stay top of the bill.

We do that, of course – and I put here some illustrations which more tie to the Heineken brand. You have to imagine we have 235 other brands to cater for, but obviously the bulk of the efforts go to the Heineken brand. We have been expanding the contract for the UEFA Champions League up to 2015. That's one important step we took in the first half of the year. As I told you earlier, our intention was to go from – with the Heineken brand – from a world brand to a global brand. We have been taking these steps, and we are there now.

One has to realize, last year we were – if the recipe is very much centralized and nobody can touch on the label – that is always pretty centralized – but the advertising in our world was pretty decentralized. Everybody could give it, around a central brief or an image, a little bit of its own tweak. But as a result, there's been lot of overspending and under-efficiency and not having the real image of being a global brand – which we are, because we're sold in 179 countries. We were working with 27 agencies, just to give you a flavor of the cumbersomeness that it takes to drive such as brand. So we have been restructuring that quite a bit.

We work now with three agencies, and we have been launching global campaigns around a theme of "Open Your World." They are expressed by two commercial. The one was "The Entrance," which you can see on YouTube, but we will share them at the end of my presentation here. Followed by another one called "The Date," which will be rolled out on classic media as from September. The "Open Your World" campaigns received five awards lately in the 2011 Cannes Lions international creativity festival. That's a testimony to the excellence of what we are doing.

We invested also a lot in digital media. If you look at the Facebook page of Heineken, in the beer category, it's number one in the world by a big margin. And the good news is that number two is also brand of Heineken; that is Dos Equis. So – and this is typical in the social media, where you're talked about and you're part of the conversation. Hence, again, the attention we devote to digital media. You have picked up that we entered into a global advertising agreement with Google relating to YouTube. So lots of initiatives also taken in the new media.

At the same time, this – our marketing excellence, brand expression excellence, exercising. At the same time, we work also on commercial capability building. I would just highlight amongst the many initiatives that we have on the ground, the one which concerns predominantly Europe and the off-trade, where we have set up a global key account management, we are perhaps the first brewer to do that in Europe. We have a global brand, Heineken, and we are in the process of setting up more global brands, like Desperados and also Strongbow cider. And it is very much to develop category leadership, which is building win-win situations and get out of the eternal vicious circle of only negotiating about the price conditions, that was in for both parties. And to do that on a pan-European basis. Now, this is up and running. We are now running for close to a year, and it starts to yield its first results.

It expresses also in the supermarket in building the in-store theater. Category leadership is about being visible in the store and using the store as a display and a communication vehicle for your brands. Classically, most of the countries, if you look at the beer shelves, they are one of the most poor one you can find, as opposed to the wine shelves, which are much more – now, if you look at that and without copying what other people are doing in cosmetics or wine, you have to find your own way originally to create a theater for your brand in the store. And that is where our people are concentrating themselves.

Now this is just to give you a flavor, where is the money going, and the next page to show the results. Here, I show the results on Heineken. Every year, or every half year, we update you with what is the Heineken brand doing. Yet again, it is growing above the rest of the portfolio, making the point that despite the crisis or the muted consumer confidence, being in the premium segment and devoting a lot of attention in the premium segment is still the right thing to do.

You see that in all geographies except Central and Eastern Europe, we have been living to that promise. Central and Eastern Europe, it's a little bit of a distorted view here. On the one hand, the overall portfolio volume went up 8.6%, a big increase because of the bounce-back of Russia. And on the other hand, Heineken minus 2.9%, which is entirely due to the lackluster performance of Greece, which has been very hardly hit by the unfolding economic crisis in the – ongoing economic crisis in that country. So that gives a little bit of a distorted picture.

But overall, we can say that the Heineken brand has been performing well, with stellar performance in a number of countries – Vietnam, but also France in the mature market, Brazil, fantastic performance, Chile, Nigeria, China, Russia, UK, and Taiwan are – certainly have been over this first half year the star performers. With lower volumes in Greece and still lower volumes in the U.S., but I will come back to that.

Result also is that we have been for five years in a row extending our leadership position in the international premium segment. We're twice as big as our immediate follower, being Corona, and our brand share stand at 20.6% of the segment at the end of 2010, and it's our intention to continue to gain share in that important segment, which frankly we helped to create but which we still want to lead going forward.

The next slide is to show you that over the last years we have been devoting a lot of our business development activities towards creating platforms for growth in markets where economic development and demographic developments and the necessary political stability work hand in hand. Beer is a business which needs demographics. So that's a very simple statement, but you have also to invest there where it happens.

Now, we have been rebalancing our portfolio quite a bit. It's a process which happened effectively over 10 years, but certainly after the acquisition of FEMSA we – it kind of tilted the barrier over half. You see that at the end of the half 2011, 62% of our group beer volume comes from these emerging markets or growing markets, and 55% of our pro forma EBIT comes from there. Obviously, in these high-growth markets, we have a number of ventures where we consolidate only our part of the net profit, but we participate in fast-growing profit pools.

So we're living up to that promise. Just to show you that the whole growth – and 95% of the growth that we have in the first half came from this platform, just underlining the importance of our policy. Obviously, I will come back on the regional overlook, or more details about it.

And the last point I'd like to highlight is the integration of FEMSA beer activities, as it is a recent acquisition – I – kind of go in a little bit. We are on track for delivering the cost synergies. They stand at €87 million out of the targeted €150 million over the two countries, so we are absolutely on track delivering the cost energies. If you look into where they are, in Mexico they are essentially in purchasing, administration, and head office. That is where – not that much in brewing in Mexico, where it is well organized. And then also a big part comes from route-to-market optimization initiatives.

In view to reduce the cost of distribution sales and warehousing, so we have been reviewing the whole direct-delivery system and reorganizing that and also cutting layers of command, making it a flatter organization. So a number of very key initiatives to be more cost efficient, that has led to the a personnel reduction of about 1,500 people over the last year, just to give you a glimpse of how extensive that is in that country. On the side of Brazil, the cost optimization is much more on the brewing side. Their best practices coming back from Heineken in the brewing are absolutely key to make lead way into cost synergies or improvement of our cost base.

And when we talk, then, on the other side on the optimization, key initiatives which are there to boost revenues. Then, again, I split it into the two countries. In Mexico, we have been revising the price architecture. What we mean by that is to laddering the prices more in the market than they were before. Obviously the introduction of locally produced Heineken is not only what happened in the first half, and that was celebrated, and it's a new start.

But also the coming of the Heineken gives the opportunity to price ladder the rest of your portfolio; brands like Indio have been slightly repositioned. Regional brands have been repositioned. It's to create more leeway in your stratification of prices. So far, the Mexican domestic portfolio was very much at the same kind of price level. So we have been extending the price levering. These effects, they play over a number of years, but it is very important to gradually do that.

The essence of our brand portfolio is, on the one hand we have been retreating a number of brands out of their national positioning. Sol is clearly destined to be positioned in the south of Mexico. So we have been retreating from central or west. So that also leads to some market share losses, which are planned for, if you will. We'll redeploy – we're not yet there, but we are in the process of redeploying a regional brand like Carta Blanca in the north. We see a high growth, and that on the back of a price repositioning of Dos Equis, which is growing quite nicely. And Dos Equis has been clearly positioned as a national brand, as well as Indio and the Heineken brand, and then finally, the Tecate brand, which has a regular variant and a light variant. You see clearly that the light variant is really taking a dominant role in that growing light segment in Mexico. It's really flying, growing double digits, coming from the north, but extending gradually, nationally on a credible basis. So that's how our portfolio is, broad line, kind of unfolding. There's still a lot of work ahead, but I feel we made a good progress over the last six months certainly.

In Brazil, there we go for segment leadership. We have a distant number four or a weak number four position, if you consider our total position, with some regional strongholds. We use the Kaiser – or Heineken do Brasil today – production network, the strongholds, and the Coca-Cola distribution network and relationship entirely to boost the Heineken sales in the premium segment. We have been growing the brand nicely again, 50% year on year in the first half. So that policy is yielding. So that investment comes up from the profits we will make over time, but clearly our aim is to develop Heineken. And by total focus on the Heineken brand, we're getting traction on that, growing the Heineken brand in Brazil. That's where we concentrate on in Brazil.

With that – I gave you some highlights about how it's going in Mexico and Brazil, our most recent acquisition. I normally do a very extended tour across all our geographies. You have read that all in the press release; we give a lot of details country by country. You will see in the attachments of the presentation you have, in the back of it, some slides region by region. So I will only make some highlights region by region of the results, commenting on the figures you see here on the screen.

As I told you earlier, Western Europe – and we didn't witness that for quite a long time – had a positive volume development. The off-trade performed quite well in Europe across Europe. The on-trade is still under pressure because of consumer confidence. The good control – the (20:54) countries which yielded the most growth have been France, Italy, and Ireland, with some weaker performance coming out of the Netherlands. The strong profit growth obviously reflect the strong performance in the TCM programs. And Western Europe continues to be a strong cash flow generator for the Heineken Group. Obviously we benefited from a very nice start from weather conditions point of view in the first half and particularly in the first quarter. We will see it in the outlook that, of course, was eaten away again by a bad summer in July and August.

In Central and Eastern Europe, the highlights are that the strong volume growth, two-thirds of that comes from Russia. So we bounced back quite nicely from last year, weak position. You will remember we increased the prices on the back of an excise duty increase, and we lost a lot of volume. We perhaps went too far. We had a lot of repair to do over second half of last year and first half of this year. We're coming back to a level close of where we were before; however, with a lesser mix than we were there, but at least on a scale and distribution-wise we are coming back and we are still making progress in Russia. Volumes in Poland, Romania, and Austria were also growing, and Greece was noticeably declining in the mid-teens for essentially economic reasons, and not for competitive reasons. And I would say the decline in profit in that region is entirely due to the lower price mix in Russia and Poland, and the declining sales in Greece explains the bulk of the decrease. All the others have been posting positive performance.

When we turn to the Americas, I devote lot of attention to the FEMSA Group. Just to add to Mexico that if you take the sales, like for like, the first six months, so you take out all the consolidation, our sales grew by 0.8% in Mexico on a market which grew somewhere between 4% and 5%. So we lost market share in volume, a little bit less in value. And part of it was planned, and part of it is also due to intensified competitive activity, which we acknowledge. That is the performance of Mexico. Financially, the Mexican operation is performing noticeably better than the year before. So we're making, absolutely, progress in terms of margins and the financial contribution coming out of Mexico.

I talked about the good performance of Brazil in terms of Heineken sales. The USA shipments were yet again under pressure, minus 4% – where you look at the shipments over depletions is minus 4%, with the same pattern of decline in sales as the Dutch portfolio, but not totally compensated by the strong growth still essentially from Dos Equis in the United States. The other operations in the Caribbean, Central America, CCU, grew all their volumes and their profits, so they're doing fine, I would say.

Then we turn to Africa and the Middle East – a little bit less growth than you're used to see coming out of Africa. You can entirely attribute that to the performance of Egypt, which for, again, not a competitive situation, but a macro and economic and political situation, is suffering. The domestic market in Egypt is rebouncing quite well. It's still under pre-revolution level. But it's coming close to the pre-revolution level. It is essentially the tourist market which is still only driving at 50% of its old level, and that explains quite a gap in Egypt, as well as the devaluation of the naira, which explains in the profit via (25:13) also the difference, I would say, in the usual growth you see from Africa and Middle East and what we see now. I have to say that otherwise than these two factors, the underlying performance of our operation is extremely good.

And now finally, ending with Asia Pacific. We maintained a strong growth momentum. We have three building blocks. We have our own export and licensing operations. Those are small pearls, but very profitable pearls, in Taiwan, Korea, which grew yet again. We could even halt our decline of sales of Heineken in Hong Kong. We bent that curve; that was good news. We have seen that after the catastrophe in Japan, sales of Heineken came back nicely. So out of our own operation, export, and licensing operation, we have only good news to tell. The same goes about APB, stellar performance – or sterling performance coming from APB, with, again, good – a particular mention to Vietnam despite the weakness of the dong. And of course, finally our position in India. UBL posted again a growth of volume of 11% over the first half, commanding a market share of 50%, growing and in great shape.

As I told you earlier, we opened a new brewery in China, brand new, which is catered just to produce premium products. On the other hand, you might have noticed that APB, in a well-thought, strategic move, we have been bundling our mainstream positions and joint ventures. We sold our stake in Kingway as well as in the DaFuHao breweries recently in order to concentrate our strategy in China on segment leadership, based on brands Heineken and Tiger.

Now, this closes our regional overview. I now go through the outlook that we released this morning. The outlook is basically to say that organically we expect the net profit to come out at the same level as last year. That caution on the backdrop of rather positive half-year result is motivated essentially by, first of all, weather conditions in Europe, which has dented quite the sales in Europe – across Europe. Just have to look out of the window; July and August have not been particularly strong. That has an effect as we go into the second half.

The second factor is obviously weakening consumer confidence. I think we would be stupid to ignore it. That is unfolding in parts of the world, in the Northern Hemisphere, particularly in the United States and in Europe. We have to reckon that it translates – most of the time, our experience is that it translates – or – either in down trading or in sales in the on-trade, which are under pressure because people just go marginally less out, but that has a big effect on our industry. So we have to caution for that one.

And last but not least, that we will not bend our plans sustaining the development of our brands. Those are long-haul efforts, and in view of that uncertainty that we face, and a bad summer, that is not going to be a reason to curtail in our marketing spending. We will continue the programs and roll them out because we go for market share and for additional top line on the medium and the long term.

Now, these three factors together brought us to bring this guidance this morning. On the other side, we continue to say that in Sub-Saharan Africa, in Asia Pacific, and in Latin, America we will continue to benefit from a strong demand. So that stays well in place. I end by saying that we're happier to take the long view, and going over a bad summer and perhaps some weakening consumer confidence in some places, which we all have to cope with, what Heineken is building – is working on – it's building sustainable – sustainable and the actual business (29:43) sustainable growth platforms.

So we will continue to concentrate ourselves on increasing our exposure to higher-growth markets going forward, that you can expect us to do that with capital discipline, obviously. Now, our entrants in Nigeria and Ethiopia are just testimony to that. We will continue to leverage our leadership in Europe; I said it many times. Yes, Europe does not benefit from demographics, but it stays a huge profit pool for us, a huge cash flow generation, and we have to leverage that leadership top line but also on the cost-line basis, and we will continue to do that. We will roll out a new TCM planner from 2012. We have initiatives like Global Business Services going on, creating shared financial service center for the whole of Europe, the establishment of a buy-sell model for our purchasing activity, a better leverage of our IT infrastructure for the sales organizations. Those are all activities that we are deploying currently, and often the cost comes in front of the benefit. But leveraging our leadership in Europe is absolutely and continue to be high on our agenda on these two dimensions: investing in top-line growth, market share innovation, but also continuing reducing our cost base. There is still work to be done.

The third pillar is obviously the Heineken brand. We will continue to dedicate a disproportionate effort to that brand, which brings us a disproportionate profitability to our company, and stay on course with that. By continue to focusing on that agenda, we remain absolutely confident that Heineken is in great shape to continue to grow in the future.

With that, I thank you for your attention. And before I hand over to René, who will give more details about our results, I will share with you a commercial. The commercial is one which we – it's "The Date." It's going to be released on television, and as from September, you can see – some of you might have seen it on YouTube. What one has to realize, the idea of global advertising came when we made in the Netherlands, the "Walking-Fridge." You remember the "Walking Fridge," which we showed you, and the thing went on YouTube, and it hit after two years, 8 million hits – two years.

When "The Entrance" was launched as a global campaign, we hit 4 million hits after four months. "The Date" has passed and crossed the 8 million hits in YouTube, just one and a half months after its release. So that's how fast it goes, but this measurement gives you also a confidence in the power of the campaigns that you are launching. Now you've got the latest one to see, so.

But what I will do is take you as usual through the financials and give you a little bit more background. Before we go into the figures, I'd like to remind you that we made a few restatements to the 2010 figures. They have been restated as well on group level as on regional level to take into account three accounting changes. One is the new accounting policy on employee benefits regarding pensions. Secondly, we shifted – we had the managerial transfer of the Mexican packaging business from the Americas into Head Office. And the third is the reallocation of some management costs from the regions to Head Office reflecting a different way of working, like we explained to you in February. In the press release, the financial impact of these changes and what the restatement has been, I explained in great detail.

Secondly, we introduced a new metric, total consolidated volume. So next to total consolidated – or to consolidated beer volume, we have total consolidated volume, which includes, next to beer, also cider, soft drinks, and other beverages, as long as they are produced by fully consolidated companies. But it also includes the third-party products, which we sell through our wholesale business. And finally, it includes the Heineken brands produced and sold under license by third parties. And by giving that metrics, we closed the gap between the volume development and the volume impact on revenues. As you will see, not completely, because there's a country mix in between, but we make it much better understandable.

Now, looking at the figures, I will dig into many of them, but let me just focus on the organic EBIT growth of 3.9%, €45 million, and that was driven by the growth in revenues, together with TCM savings on one hand and higher marketing costs on the other hand. But it is very much it starts (36:50) with the top line.

If you look at that on a regional level, Western Europe and Africa were the big drivers of that organic EBIT growth. When you look here on the page later on, I will exclude that always, but when you look at the reported EBIT and net profit, they are obviously influenced by the shift in exceptional items, and they go from a net gain of €73 million last year, in the first half of the year, versus a net cost of €89 million this year. Last year, just to remind you, we had the sale of our businesses in Indonesia and New Caledonia to our joint venture partner APB, and that yielded a capital gain of €199 million.

Looking at the top line, revenues grew 11% to €8.4 billion. The net effect of new consolidations was €700 million or 9.3% of that, and that is by and large the effect of the first-time consolidation for the four months of the operations in Mexico and Brazil, which is then partly offset by sale of Waverley, our wholesale business in the UK, in the midst of last year and the deconsolidation of Multi Bintang and GBNC in the Asia Pacific regions.

Currencies had an effect of €112 million negative on revenues; that's 1.5%. And that is mainly the Nigerian naira, which devaluated 8% in the first half of the year versus the euro. Organically, revenues increased 3.3%, benefiting from the higher volumes but also from a positive price-mix movement, and that was up 1.1% in the first half of the year.

The effect of the higher volumes on revenues was 2.2%, and so as I said before, that doesn't compare exactly with the 2.7% growth in total consolidated volume. The difference is the strong growth we had in Russia, a market with a lower revenue per hectoliter, so that country mix has an influence on that.

Looking at EBIT, as always, I focus on the beia numbers. So I take them before exceptional items and the amortization of brands and customer relations. EBIT beia increased 11% to €1.259 billion. And the net impact of the first-time consolidations accounted for €96 million or 8.4%. And again that's mostly Mexico, Brazil, a little bit offset by Indonesia and New Caledonia.

The currencies had a negative impact of €20 million, 1.7%. And again, that was the naira, which took – more than half of that €20 million was linked to the naira. So overall, 3.9% organic growth in EBIT, €45 million, driven by the volume growth in all regions; higher prices implemented in main or key markets like Nigeria, Mexico, the UK, France; mitigating the effect of higher input costs, although the effect in the first half was 0.5%, but still limited; increased sales of the Heineken brand and costs savings, predominately achieved in Europe, partly reinvested in higher marketing investments. Operating profits, without the associates and JVs, grew 10%, and our operating margin stayed stable at 13.8%.

When we look at the EBIT from a geographical split, you see that here on the slide I would like to make a few remarks. First of all, if you would compare this table with a couple of years ago, you see very strong differences. The growth in Africa for many, many years now and the acquisitions in the Americas have significantly changed the balance between the regions and have reduced the weight of the more developed markets.

Secondly, you see Asia Pacific here having a small contribution in the chart, and that's obviously the result of the fact that we accounted in the way we do joint ventures are not included in the consolidated figures, and we only take our equity share of net profit in the account. And as the biggest part of our business in Asia Pacific is exploited in JVs, APB, UB in India, you see that Asia is relatively unrepresented in this geographical chart.

Second remark is that all regions generated positive organic EBIT growth. The exception is Central and Eastern Europe, as Jean-François explained. To a great extent, the effect of Greece, but also the input cost and price-mix degradation in Poland and Russia played a role there.

And last thing, which is not in the geographical split but important to mention, is the EBIT at Head Office – Head Office and elimination – we lost a bucket. That EBIT decreased organically by €39 million, and that reflects the higher costs we are making on one hand on global marketing campaigns. So a big part there is invested in marketing, but it is also the cost, as Jean-François already said, behind initiatives like Global Business Services, where you have first to invest to get these things up and running before you reap the benefits.

Looking at net profit, net profits grew also 11% to €694 million, and 5.7% of that is organic, obviously driven on one hand by the better operational performance, but also by a 30% organic decrease in interest expenses. And that was partly offset by an increase in the tax rate that has to do with a different country mix, but it has also to do with some incidental factors. Austria changed the tax law on the deductibility of interest costs, and that has yielded in an higher tax rate in the first half of the year.

Currency fluctuations lowered the net profit by €9 million, and the first-time consolidations added €41 million or 6.5%. On an diluted basis, the EPS shows a different picture, obviously, than the net profit itself. EPS was decreasing by 1.7%, and that is due to the increased number of shares, which increased to 591 million in the first half of the year compared with the 527 million which we had in the same period last year. And I would like to elaborate a bit on the average share calculation, because there are quite some different estimates in the market that we have sent out in (45:19) consensus, and you see a wide range of calculations. And I think that has mainly to do with the treatment of the ASDI.

So, once more, when we acquired the beer operations of FEMSA, we – apart from issuing the 86 million shares, we committed to deliver another 29 million HNV shares, and that could be new or existing shares under the terms of the Allotted Share Delivery Instrument. Well, these shares are treated as new shares, so as of the 30th of April, 2010, these 29 million shares were increasing equity. But as we are repurchasing these shares on the market, gradually they will diminish that amount, and obviously that effect you'll have to wait according to the relative months.

So if we go back to the table, you have to note two things. First of all, the additional 86 million shares which we issued are now fully incorporated in our shares. So they'll count for the full year, where last year they were only counting for eight months. And that brings the total issued shares up to 576 million.
